title: OpenSSL CMS AuthEnvelopedData Critical Stack Buffer Overflow (CVE-2025-15467) Enables Pre-Authentication Remote Code Execution Across All OpenSSL 3.x Deployments, Discovered by AI-Assisted Research Team AISLE

timeline.event: AISLE AI-assisted research team (Stanislav Fort) discovers CVE-2025-15467 and reports it to OpenSSL project
AISLE publishes blog announcing they discovered all 12 vulnerabilities in the upcoming OpenSSL security advisory
OpenSSL publishes security advisory and releases patched versions 3.6.1, 3.5.5, 3.4.4, 3.3.6, and 3.0.19
JFrog Security Research confirms code execution is achievable, though practical exploitation requires bypassing modern mitigations (Stack Canaries, ASLR, DEP)
AISLE publishes detailed technical deep dive into CVE-2025-15467 exploitation mechanics

simple_summary.what_happened: A critical stack buffer overflow vulnerability was discovered in OpenSSL, the most widely used cryptographic library that secures most of the internet's encrypted communications. The flaw exists in the CMS (Cryptographic Message Syntax) AuthEnvelopedData processing code when handling AEAD (Authenticated Encryption with Associated Data) ciphers. An attacker can trigger the overflow by sending a specially crafted encrypted message to any application that uses OpenSSL to process CMS/PKCS#7 content, potentially achieving remote code execution without needing any credentials. What makes this discovery particularly notable is that all 12 vulnerabilities in the January 2026 OpenSSL advisory were found by AISLE, an AI-assisted security research team, marking a significant milestone in AI-driven vulnerability discovery. JFrog researchers confirmed that code execution is achievable through this vulnerability.
simple_summary.who_is_affected: Any system or application using OpenSSL versions 3.0 through 3.6 (prior to the patched releases) that processes CMS or PKCS#7 encrypted content is potentially vulnerable. This includes web servers (Apache, Nginx), email servers handling S/MIME encrypted messages, VPN appliances, certificate authorities, and any application using OpenSSL's CMS API. Major Linux distributions (Red Hat, Ubuntu, Debian, SUSE) that ship OpenSSL 3.x are affected. Critically, OpenSSL 1.1.1 and 1.0.2 are NOT affected. Cloud infrastructure, container environments, and IoT devices running OpenSSL 3.x for TLS/SSL operations may also be at risk depending on their CMS usage.
simple_summary.what_attackers_do: Step 1: The attacker identifies a target system that processes CMS (Cryptographic Message Syntax) content using OpenSSL 3.x, such as an email server handling S/MIME encrypted messages, a web application processing PKCS#7 signatures, or any service accepting encrypted CMS data. Step 2: The attacker crafts a malicious CMS AuthEnvelopedData message with a specially constructed AEAD cipher configuration that triggers a stack buffer overflow during the decryption process, overwriting critical memory on the stack. Step 3: The overflow occurs before any authentication or credential checks, meaning the attacker needs no valid credentials, certificates, or prior access to exploit the vulnerability. Step 4: Through careful control of the overflowed buffer, the attacker can redirect program execution to their own shellcode, though they must bypass modern memory protection mechanisms like Stack Canaries, ASLR, and DEP to achieve reliable code execution. Step 5: If successful, the attacker gains code execution with the privileges of the application processing the CMS content, potentially root/system level on servers, enabling full system compromise, data theft, or lateral movement.
what_you_should_do: Immediately update OpenSSL to patched versions: 3.6.1, 3.5.5, 3.4.4, 3.3.6, or 3.0.19 on all systems
Apply operating system vendor patches from Red Hat, Ubuntu, Debian, SUSE, and other distributions that include the OpenSSL fix
Inventory all systems and applications using OpenSSL 3.x; prioritize patching internet-facing services that process CMS/PKCS#7 content
If immediate patching is not possible, consider disabling AEAD cipher support in CMS operations as a temporary mitigation
Verify that modern exploit mitigations (ASLR, Stack Canaries, DEP/NX) are enabled on all systems running OpenSSL to increase the difficulty of exploitation
simple_summary.why_this_is_serious: OpenSSL is the cryptographic foundation of the internet, used by millions of servers, applications, and devices worldwide. A pre-authentication RCE vulnerability in OpenSSL has the potential for catastrophic impact comparable to Heartbleed (CVE-2014-0160), which affected an estimated 17% of the internet's servers. While practical exploitation requires bypassing modern memory protections, JFrog has confirmed that code execution is achievable, and sophisticated attackers routinely overcome these mitigations. The fact that an AI-assisted research team discovered all 12 vulnerabilities in this advisory highlights that AI is accelerating vulnerability discovery, and it is only a matter of time before similar AI techniques are used offensively. Organizations that delay patching are exposed to a high-impact vulnerability with a massive attack surface.

tactics.description: Exploits the OpenSSL CMS buffer overflow in internet-facing services (email servers, web applications, VPN gateways) that process CMS/PKCS#7 content
Triggers code execution through the stack buffer overflow when the target application processes the malicious CMS AuthEnvelopedData message
If the OpenSSL-using application runs as root or a privileged service account, the exploit yields elevated privileges on the target system
The vulnerability is in the cryptographic processing layer, making exploitation difficult to detect with standard application-layer security tools
Even without achieving code execution, the buffer overflow reliably crashes the application, enabling denial of service against any OpenSSL 3.x service processing CMS content

detection_guidance.summary: Detection is challenging because the vulnerability is in the cryptographic processing layer, making payload inspection difficult. Focus on detecting exploitation outcomes (crashes, unexpected process behavior) and ensuring vulnerability management identifies all unpatched OpenSSL instances.

log_sources.description: Monitor for unexpected crashes or segmentation faults in applications using OpenSSL, particularly email servers (Postfix, Sendmail, Exim) and web servers processing CMS content
Run vulnerability scans to identify all systems with OpenSSL 3.0-3.6 prior to patched versions; prioritize internet-facing services
Track OpenSSL package versions across all systems using configuration management tools to verify patch deployment
Deploy signatures to detect malformed CMS/PKCS#7 content in email (S/MIME) and web traffic that may indicate exploitation attempts

what_to_look_for.indicator: OpenSSL application crashes with stack buffer overflow
what_to_look_for.description: Segmentation faults or stack smashing detected errors in applications using OpenSSL CMS functions indicate possible exploitation attempts
what_to_look_for.log_field: signal='SIGSEGV' OR signal='SIGABRT' AND process IN ('httpd', 'nginx', 'postfix', 'sendmail')

what_to_look_for.description: Systems running OpenSSL versions 3.0.0-3.0.18, 3.3.0-3.3.5, 3.4.0-3.4.3, 3.5.0-3.5.4, or 3.6.0 are vulnerable

what_to_look_for.indicator: Malformed S/MIME messages targeting email servers
what_to_look_for.description: Email messages with unusual CMS AuthEnvelopedData structures designed to trigger the buffer overflow during processing

what_to_look_for.indicator: Unexpected outbound connections after OpenSSL crashes
what_to_look_for.description: If exploitation succeeds, the compromised process may initiate reverse shell connections or download second-stage payloads
what_to_look_for.log_field: process_crash=true AND subsequent_outbound_connection=true AND dst_port IN (4444, 8443, 9001)

immediate_actions.action: Patch OpenSSL to the latest version immediately
immediate_actions.description: Update OpenSSL to version 3.6.1, 3.5.5, 3.4.4, 3.3.6, or 3.0.19 depending on your branch. Apply vendor OS patches from Red Hat, Ubuntu, Debian, etc. This is the most critical action.
immediate_actions.command: openssl version && sudo apt update && sudo apt upgrade openssl

immediate_actions.description: Identify every system, container, and appliance running OpenSSL 3.x. Check servers, load balancers, VPN appliances, mail servers, and container base images. Note: OpenSSL 1.1.1 and 1.0.2 are NOT affected.
Ensure that ASLR, Stack Canaries, and DEP/NX are enabled on all systems. These mitigations make exploitation significantly harder even on unpatched systems.

immediate_actions.action: Monitor for application crashes on critical services
immediate_actions.description: Set up alerting for unexpected crashes or restarts of services that use OpenSSL for CMS/PKCS#7 processing, particularly email servers handling S/MIME content.
Rebuild and redeploy container images that bundle OpenSSL 3.x. Many container base images include vulnerable versions. Scan your container registry for affected images.
